titleproper.value: Guide to Maria Irene Fornés Papers <num>MSS.413</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2017-05-17T13:45:51</date>

extent.value: in 38 manuscript boxes, 1 oversize folder, and 14 computer files.

abstract.value: Maria Irene Fornés (b. 1930) is a Cuban-American avant-garde dramatist, director, and teacher of playwriting.  Her work, most particularly associated with both the Off-Broadway and Off-Off Broadway movements of the 1960s and New York City's "downtown scene" of the 1980s, has had a major influence on several generations of American playwrights.  Winner of 9 Obies, as well as numerous additional awards and honors, Fornés wrote over 50 works for the stage between 1961 and 2001.  Her best-known pieces are <title render="italic">Fefu and Her Friends</title> (1977), <title render="italic">The Danube</title> (1982), <title render="italic">Mud</title> (1983), and <title render="italic">Promenade</title> (1965), a musical play.  The papers document more than half of Fornés’ entire <emph render="italic">oevre</emph>, in original and annotated playscripts, libretti, and adapted works dating from 1961 through 2001; they also document Fornés’ writing process through notes, scenarios, character sketches, and other writings. The remainder of the papers consists of business and professional documents, personal correspondence, family papers, and subject files.  The entire collection spans 1909 through 2005, but most of its materials date from the 1980s and 1990s.

p.value: Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

Published citations should take the
following form:<lb/><lb/>
Identification of item,  date (if known); Maria Irene Fornés Papers; MSS 413; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

In 2001 illness forced Irene Fornés to retire.  Her last completed play (first produced in 2000) was <title render="italic">Letters from Cuba</title>; her last working play was<title render="italic">27 Rue de Fleurus</title>, a piece about the life of Gertrude Stein.

The papers span 1909 to 2005, with the bulk from the 1980s and 1990s, and were created during the course of Irene Fornés’ playwriting and directing, teaching, administrative and organizational activities and personal relationships. They include play scripts in both paper and electronic form, production notes, set designs and drawings, correspondence, family papers, newspaper clippings, play and book reviews, itineraries, travel ephemera,  grant proposals, contracts, play programs, workshop exercises, and student work, as well as notes, play ideas, scenarios, scripted dialog and monologues, and other writings in process. The collection illustrates writing and research processes of a playwright, teaching playwriting, and some aspects of the business and financial sides of the life of a working artist; it also includes personal correspondence and family documents used as source materials for dramatic pieces, and internal and administrative documents of an ethnic theater arts organization.

dsc.value:
Series I: Play Scripts and Production Records8.5 Linear Feetin 16.5 manuscript boxes and 13 computer files.1961-2001Arrangement

This series was divided into two subseries to distinguish between Fornés' work as a writer and director of her own plays and her work directing and translating plays of other authors. Folders in both subseries are arranged in alphabetical order by play title. For each title, folders are arranged by genre or document type. In cases in which plays are known by different titles, the best-known title is listed first, followed by the alternate title. Some folders may contain material for multiple titles.

Scope and Content

This series includes original and revised scripts in both paper and electronic format for a little over half of Irene Fornés’ work, including some of her earliest plays and her last working play, Rue de Fleurus (concerning Gertrude Stein). It also includes a script for Minuski, a previously-unknown work, and La Plaza Chica, Fornés' translation and adaptation of her play Abingdon Square into Spanish. In addition, there are scores for some of her plays with songs; a libretto for an opera; and scripts and staging notes for Fornés’ directing, translating, and adapting of other writers’ plays or stories (such as Henrik Ibsen's Hedda Gabler and Anton Chekhov's Uncle Vanya and Drowning). There are numerous drafts or versions of Fornes’ scripts written, edited, or adapted for different productions of a play, or revised after the completion of a run of a particular production. Many of the scripts are not complete, and most of them have Fornés’ handwritten--often extensive--annotations and revisions. Production records for various stagings of her own plays and productions she directed of others’ works include memos, notes, set designs, cast lists, and calls for auditions.

The Widow--Production Photographscirca 196115827 Rue de Fleurus--Scripts and Research Materials2001, undated159-16161-16Unidentified Plays--Production Photographs, Contact Sheets, Negatives1987, undated1617-20Unidentified Play--Photographundated2.C11Unidentified Play ("Zoila Y Berta in the Malecon 1903")--Script Fragementundated1621Unidentified Play ("Rob and Tom")--Script Fragmentundated1622Subseries 2: Plays by Others Directed by Fornés1987-1994Hedda Gabler--Script and Production Notes 1987, undated1623-24It Is It Is Not (by Manuel Pereiras)--Production Materials19941625171It Is It Is Not (by Manuel Pereiras)--Scripts1994171Life is a Dream--Script Fragments, Song, Researchundated172Unidentified Play (Possibly Life Is a Dream)--Set Design and Production Snapshotsundated178Uncle Vanya--Script, Casting, Production Notes, Research1987, undated173-7Series II: Notes, Scenarios, and Writings in Process2.75 Linear Feetin 4.75 manuscript boxes.1960s-1990s, undatedScope and Content

This series contains diverse writings and drawings on paper recording Fornés’ internal artistic processes and ideas. It includes notes, scenarios, stories and character studies; dialogs, monologues and individual lines; ideas for plays, films and dances; journal and diary entries; fragments of narratives and numerous other types of writings in process; and a small amount of correspondence. Some of the writings are typed, and many are handwritten. Formats range from notebooks to the backs of envelopes and smaller scraps. Almost none of the items are dated, with the exception of a few materials from the 1980s to the 1990s. Most of the materials originally received in labeled folders retain their original folder titles (these are enclosed by quotation marks); the remaining materials have been placed in folders labeled “miscellaneous short notes.”

Business and Finance Files1.5 Linear Feetin 3 manuscript boxes.1971-2004Scope and Content

This series contains documents pertaining to Fornés’ professional activities, business, and finances, as well as some materials on her personal business and finances. These include correspondence concerning productions of her plays, requests to stage her works, project and grant proposals, contracts, statements from her agent, pay stubs, calendars, schedules, itineraries, property tax and income records, invoices for maintenance fees for her New York City condominium and for renovations to her home in Delaware County, New York.

Records0.25 Linear Feetin 1 manuscript box.1992-2000Scope and Content

Materials in this series document administrative and internal workings of one of the oldest Latino theater companies in the United States, through memos, budgets, production schedules and cast lists for INTAR productions. Fornés had a long association with the organization in a number of capacities, most notably as director and teacher of its playwrights-in-residence program.

1992-2000 Seasons1992-2000261-7Series V: Family Papers0.1 Linear Feetin 2 folders.1947-2000Scope and Content

This series contains government documents and applications for government assistance, and documents and correspondence concerning emigration from Cuba and immigration to the United States, including Irene Fornés’ naturalization certificate. Also included are affidavits and requests by Fornés and members of her extended family to Cuban and U.S. authorities to facilitate emigration of relatives in Cuba to the United States. In addition, there are applications by Fornés’ mother, Carmen Collado Fornés for public housing and her food stamp identification cards. Nongovernmental official documents such as a travel identification card for American Youth Hostels, Inc. are also part of the series.

Emigration, Immigration, and Other Documents1947-2000, undated268-9Series VI: Personal Correspondence0.25 Linear Feetin 1 manuscript box.1909-2004271-5Scope and Content

This series contains letters and cards from Irene Fornés’ family and photocopies of same, and letters between Fornés and her friends and family. These include some of the letters that Fornés drew upon as sources for two of her plays. Family correspondents in this series include Carmen Collado Fornés, Ramon Collado, Rafael Fornés, and "Pepe."

Family1909-2004271-4Friends1996-2004, undated275Series VII: Teaching Materials and Students’ Work1.25 Linear Feetin 3 manuscript boxes.1971-2005Scope and Content

This series consists of students’ handwritten, typewritten, or mimeographed scenarios; scripts for plays and playlets; stories; and poems. In addition, the series includes flyers, correspondence, exercise instructions, participant lists, play notes, and drawings that pertain to, or that arose from, Irene Fornés’ teaching and playwriting workshops. She briefly taught elementary school students, but the bulk of her students were college students and adults who were emerging playwrights. Because Fornés’ method for teaching plays included close collaboration, a number of these scripts were co-written by several different students as well as with Fornés herself (Meche is one clear example). In addition to those who received formal instruction from Fornés through workshops, lectures or classes, the series also includes materials from informal “students” of hers who may never have been enrolled in any of the courses she taught--aspiring playwrights whom she seems to have mentored or for whose work she seems to have provided criticism.

"Recommendations for My Students" (Handwritten Drafts)undated291Students' Plays--Scripts and Notes1981-2005, undated292-6301Unidentified Play--Scripts, Partial Script, and Script Fragments (Possibly by Students)2003-2004, undated302-3Workshops1982-2003304-11Series VIII: Subject/Research Files3.5 Linear Feetin 7 manuscript boxes and 1 computer file.1919-2005Scope and Content

This series includes a wide-ranging collection of materials gathered as research for Fornés’ plays on subjects as varied as fortune-telling, President John F. Kennedy’s assassination, Fidel Castro, and silent films, as well as articles documenting Fornés’ career and the reception of her plays, her interests in drama and art, and her extensive travels, as well as those of her mother. Items include biographical portraits and transcripts of interviews with Fornés; newspaper and magazine clippings; play and book reviews; programs and announcements for, and invitations to, plays, dances, musical performances, art exhibits and openings; maps and travel ephemera; catalogs; posters; photographs; song lyrics; and recipes. Most of those materials originally received in labeled folders have retained their original folder titles (indicated by by quotation marks).
